Award.AwardTitle: IGERT-CIF21: Computation-Enabled Design and Manufacturing of High Performance Materials

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award prepares Ph.D. students at the Georgia Institute of Technology with the tools to improve the efficiency, design, and manufacturing of new materials. While providing students with interdisciplinary training in computing, mathematics, and material sciences, the program promotes entrepreneurial approaches to developing new materials into products for the global market.

Intellectual Merit: The goal of this training program is to produce scientists and engineers who will develop and use data analytics, modeling, and simulation methods to advance the fields of materials design and manufacturing. Trainees will quantify the microstructures that comprise materials and will develop algorithms and software to represent and transform these microstructures. Additionally, trainees will explore application challenges such as creating light-weight materials for energy-efficient vehicles and accelerating the development of new technologies such as additive manufacturing. Through internships in industry and a curriculum that combines business with materials science, mathematics and computing, trainees learn how to apply their research to commercial product development.

Broader Impacts: By increasing the efficiency of materials development and manufacturing, this program contributes to America's competitiveness in an increasingly globalized marketplace and contributes to the creation of new and sustainable materials and technologies. Moreover, this traineeship program helps students develop the skills and tools needed to pursue careers at the intersection of materials science, mathematics and computing.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to establish new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries, and to engage students in understanding the processes by which research is translated to innovations for societal benefit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The FLAMEL (From Learning, Analytics, and Materials to Entrepreneurship and Leadership) doctoral traineeship program was a five-year program that funded two-year doctoral student traineeships from August 2014 until August 2019. The program was developed to prepare Ph.D. students at the Georgia Institute of Technology with the tools to improve the efficiency, design, and manufacturing of new materials. The program provided students with interdisciplinary training in computing, mathematics, material sciences, and entrepreneurship to accelerate the development of new materials and transition these materials into products for the global marketplace. The program produced scientists and engineers who will develop and use data analytics, modeling, and simulation methods to advance the field of materials design and manufacturing.

Trainees developed the knowledge and skills to quantify the microstructures that comprise materials as well as develop algorithms and software to represent and transform these microstructures. Additionally, trainees explored application challenges such as creating light-weight materials for energy-efficient vehicles and accelerating the development of new technologies such as additive manufacturing. By increasing the efficiency of materials development and manufacturing, this program contributed to America’s competitiveness in an increasingly globalized marketplace and contributed to the creation of new and sustainable materials and technologies. Moreover, this traineeship program helped students develop the skills and tools needed to pursue careers at the intersection of materials science, mathematics and computing.

The IGERT project produced a number of new research results, documented and disseminated to the research community through 56 conference and journal publications and 60 oral presentations. In addition, substantial efforts were made to sustain this activity beyond the completion of NSF IGERT funding. IGERT faculty were successful in launching a number of new research projects in the IGERT topic area, ensuring continued research in the materials informatics area in the years ahead. Further, IGERT faculty led in the acquisition of computing equipment, and the development of cyberinfrastructure to support these research activities. IGERT activities were closely integrated with broader activities at Georgia Tech to establish new interdisciplinary research centers in materials and data science to grow and support research in materials informatics, among other areas. Other activities led to the development of a research agenda for the modeling and simulation community.

The 29 faculty advisors and 26 doctoral student trainees supported by the program spanned 8 different departments at Georgia Tech. They conducted interdisciplinary research in a wide range of areas such as data-driven design of glass fibers, plastics, metals, composite membranes and films, flexible semiconductors and liquid crystals, and materials for additive manufacturing. Computational techniques such as machine learning, modeling and simulation (including high performance computing), information visualization systems, and bio-inspired modeling and design were developed and/or applied to address issues in materials design and manufacturing.

The IGERT project achieved several major educational accomplishments that will have a lasting impact well beyond the completion of NSF funding. First and foremost, the program led to the development of new courses and establishment of curriculum at the intersection of materials science and engineering, and computing. More broadly, the IGERT curriculum is part of broader efforts at Georgia Tech to establish curriculum and formal education programs in computational science and engineering, a discipline focused on computer-based models of natural and engineered systems. These programs are having a large impact on education at Georgia Tech. In addition, other FLAMEL activities in areas such as communications, leadership training, and work in industry have significantly enriched the professional development of IGERT trainees. Overall, the IGERT program has led to substantive advances in education that will have much impact at Georgia Tech into the foreseeable future.

The program developed new workforce trained in data science and exploitation of advanced computational methods in materials design and manufacturing. The program was successful in attracting trainees spanning a broad range of expertise and backgrounds, demonstrating that student interest in this area can be sustained well beyond the completion of NSF funding. The program was successful in attracting women and underrepresented minority students, reaching more than 50% of the funded trainees coming from underrepresented groups by the end of the program.
